Award.AwardTitle: Measuring and modeling object similarity in the brain: combining conceptual and perceptual representations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The brain uses similarity to generalize from the known to the unknown. For example, when a person encounters a new type of fruit and has to decide whether or not it is edible, the person must judge how similar it is to already known edible and inedible items. However, the type of similarity that is taken into account matters. A coconut can look like a rock (visual similarity), but for making a decision about edibility the fact that it hangs from a leafy tree (semantic similarity) is key. With funding from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Rajeev Raizada of Rochester University is investigating how the brain uses similarity to respond adaptively to changing circumstances. With an understanding of how types of similarity, such as visual and semantic similarity, are encoded in the brain, it should be possible to decode them from neural signals. In this project, Dr. Raizada is combining brain imaging with computational modeling and behavioral testing. He is developing novel methods of neural decoding to predict the similarity of brain patterns on the basis of computational models of the stimuli that people are perceiving. In addition, the methods are designed to investigate patterns across different people's brain activations.

The novel computational methods being developed in the project could have significant broader impacts, for example, such techniques underpin brain-computer interfaces that attempt to restore communication to locked-in patients. Moreover, the modeling of semantic similarity in the brain has implications for disorders such as semantic dementia. There are also possible implications for technology. The brain responds flexibly to changing circumstances, but artificial systems, in contrast, are all too often brittle. When confronted with circumstances similar, but not identical, to familiar ones, they break down. Insights into how the brain generalizes from the known to the unknown have the potential to transform our knowledge of how the brain achieves its adaptability, opening up new avenues for endowing artificial systems with similar skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project investigated the role of similarity in how the human brain represents the world. Different objects can be more or less similar to each other, e.g. an apple is more similar to a pear than it is to a truck, and different brain activation patterns can also be more or less similar to each other, e.g. two spatial patterns may be weakly or strongly correlated. The key hypothesis guiding this research was that the similarity of neural activation patterns is related to the similarity of the objects or concepts that the brain activation represents. Brain activation patterns were measured in people using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). The main measure of success in understanding the brain's representations was the accuracy with which they could be decoded, i.e. given a measured activation pattern in a person's brain, how successfully could a computer algorithm determine what that person was thinking or perceiving.

The main outcomes of the work were insights into the brain may use similarity to represent language, specifically the meanings of words. Just as objects such as apples and pears can be similar to each other, so can word meanings, e.g. the word 'heavy' is more similar in meaning to 'big' than it is to 'purple'. The researchers found that the neural pattern similarity could be used to decode people's representations of language. For example, in one study, it was found that when speakers of English read words in that language, and when speakers of Chinese read the Chinese translations of those same words, the set of neural pattern similarities within the brains of the two different language groups could be matched up with each other. Purely by matching neural similarities, it was possible to determine which English word corresponded to which Chinese word, i.e. it was possible to translate between the two languages based on brain data alone.

In another study, computational modeling of neural similarity, along with additional modeling techniques, allowed the researchers to decode the neural representations of entire sentences for the first time. The computer model could also predict the brain patterns for new sentences that it had not been trained on, as long as it had been trained on enough of the words in that sentence in different contexts. For example, the model could predict the brain pattern for "The family played at the beach," using the patterns that it had been trained on for other sentences sharing some of the same words, such as "The young girl played soccer" and "The beach was empty.

The research project also resulted in theoretical insights into the relationships between similarity in the brain and similarity in machine learning algorithms, and in new techniques for neurally decoding brain data that is optically recorded from infants.

Together, these results help to increase understanding of the fundamental question of how the brain represents the world. They also have potential practical applicability, for example in laying the foundations for one day being able to help patients with neurological damage to communicate meaning that would otherwise remain locked inside their heads.
